prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship
Remedies Table—Employment Relationship—Breach of Fiduciary Duty

head.headtext: Beyer-Brown & Associates Ltd. v. S & R Interiors Ltd.
Beyer-Brown & Associates Ltd. v. S & R Interiors Ltd., 2007 CarswellBC 522, 2007 BCSC 327

para.paratext: Judgment awarded against Mason in the amount of $105,000 plus interest, which was the amount of the profit he enjoyed.
Judgment awarded against S & R in the amount of $139,868 plus interest, this being the remaining balance of the profit for which it was responsible as a constructive trustee

For 16 years, the Defendant Mason was employed by the Plaintiff as a commission salesman in the wholesale furniture supply business. Throughout this employment, Mason secured and serviced furniture supply contracts for Canadian Citizenship and Immigration. In 2004, while still in the Plaintiff's employ, Mason failed to notify the Plaintiff that he would not be tendering a bid on its behalf for the upcoming CIC contract in time for the Plaintiff to tender a bid of its own. Rather, Mason tendered a bid on behalf of the Defendant, S & R, a company in which he had recently acquired a 50% interest. The Plaintiff did not become aware that Mason failed to tender a bid for the CIC contract on its behalf until after he had left its employ to join S & R. At that time, it was too late for the Plaintiff to submit a bid of its own. S & R was subsequently awarded the CIC contract. It was the only bid tendered. S & R fulfilled the terms of this contract. From this CIC contract, S & R derived a gross profit of $346,738. From these gross profits, S & R paid $105,000 to Mason for management fees; $129,299 to a principal of S & R and the other 50% shareholder for management fees; and $101,870 for overhead and operating costs. The remaining $10,569 was designated as profits. S & R was no longer in business and had declared bankruptcy.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Mason's tortious conduct was his failure to provide the Plaintiff with sufficient notice that he would not be tendering a bid on its behalf in time for the Plaintiff to tender a bid of its own. As a result of the pattern of behaviour, the Plaintiff came to rely upon Mason to tender this bid for it. This pattern of reliance on the Plaintiff's part gave rise to a corresponding obligation on Mason's part to notify the Plaintiff if he was not going to do the task for which it was relying upon him. That notification had to be made in sufficient time to provide the Plaintiff with the opportunity to tender a bid on its own behalf. A fiduciary relationship existed between Mason and the Plaintiff with respect to tendering the CIC bid on its behalf. For the 16 years he was employed by the Plaintiff, Mason acted as its agent with respect to the CIC contract. That is, he had scope for the exercise of some discretion or power because he had assumed the responsibility of preparing and tendering the Plaintiff's bid for the CIC contract throughout. He could unilaterally exercise that power or discretion so as to affect the Plaintiff's practical interests because the Plaintiff left it up to him to tender its bid. That is, the Plaintiff did not check with Mason each time to ensure that he was preparing its bid. Lastly, because the Plaintiff relied on Mason to tender its bid, it was vulnerable to, or at the mercy of Mason. If he failed to notify the Plaintiff that he was not tendering a bid on its behalf, the Plaintiff would be unaware of that fact and would lose the opportunity to submit a bid of its own. Though tendering a competing bid while still employed may be a breach of contract rather than a breach of fiduciary duty, in the circumstances, it was appropriate to consider it as being incidental to the breach of the fiduciary duty. That is, the conduct that resulted in the greatest harm to the Plaintiff was the loss of the opportunity to bid on the CIC contract.

As far as the measure of damages is concerned, generally speaking the measure of damages for the breach of a fiduciary obligation are the profits resulting from that breach. The policy underlying this principle is that the law of fiduciary duty has always contained within it an element of deterrence. Accordingly, this remedy does not depend on any proof that the claimant suffered any loss. It is of no consequence that the party seeking redress could not its/her/himself have taken advantage of the benefit “improperly” gained. However, if the profits enjoyed by the defendant are less than the losses proven by the plaintiff, for reasons of fairness the Court will order restitution rather than a disgorgement of profits. In other words, if the disgorgement of profits is an inadequate remedy (because the plaintiff has proven that their losses are greater than the defendant's ill-gotten profits), the measure of damages is the loss proven by the plaintiff. It is only in cases in which the plaintiff's proven losses are greater than the defendant's profits that the Court will adopt a “but for the breach of the fiduciary duty” analysis and award damages commensurate with the plaintiff's proven loss. Otherwise, the measure of damages is the defendant's profits. The court was satisfied that the plaintiff's loss would have been considerably less than the profits enjoyed by the Defendants. The “but for the breach of the fiduciary obligation” analysis results in very modest damages to the Plaintiff. That is, if Mason had provided the Plaintiff with sufficient notice, it is very unlikely that the Plaintiff would have been awarded the bid. The likelihood of the Plaintiff securing the CIC contract was no greater than 10%. The “but for” analysis results in a loss to the Plaintiff in the range of $17,500-$20,000. The profit analysis for the measure of damages, on the other hand, results in a substantially larger award. The profit of the Defendants was $244,868. This is the balance remaining after the deduction of operating/overhead expenses, excluding the $234,299 in management fees paid to Mason and Sehmbey.
